summary:
I dont really want to ship Rey with Kylo Ren.
But I would be up for shipping her with Ben Solo.
(If he ever gets his head out of...
body:
I dont really want to ship Rey with Kylo Ren.

But I would be up for shipping her with Ben Solo.

(If he ever gets his head out of his ass.)

blog.name: scarletxvision
blog.title: A Pinch of Paprika
blog.description:
Heyo!! My name is Aoife, I'm from Ireland, and I’m a lover of Marvel, the Avengers and my ultimate OTP Scarlet Vision!! 
I'm currently (not so patiently) waiting for the  WandaVision TV show which will hopefully bring back my baby boy Vision and give my powerful queen Wanda the happy ending she deserves. Until then, imma like and reblog my way through life while occasionally making the odd meme or two. Bring on 2021!!❤💚

blog.description: Kit Harington has better curls, but I am infinite; I contain multitudes. Whatever. It's not my Axminster.

tags: uuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuultimately i think its a pointless argument
because its both things and nothing at once
and the point is its empty enough of ideology that all kinds of people can read it as a power fantasy
a leftist power fantasy would have to preclude all other power fantasies
it exists in a structure that's so thoroughly rotten
talking about squaring it with leftist ideals is like joking about sunbathing while your house is on fire
summary: How do you reconcile liking Star Wars with your leftist views? I’ve read articles by leftists that either dismiss it as...
question: How do you reconcile liking Star Wars with your leftist views? I’ve read articles by leftists that either dismiss it as reactionary fascism, or embrace it as a leftist power fantasy.
answer:
I don’t!

I mean look: on 17th December 2017 I sat in the cinema and stared in kind of thrilled surprise that we were getting an actual affirmation of a) the military industrial complex and b) colonialism, explicitly from the mouth of a character played by a Vietnamese actress, and a surrounding narrative which validated her little narration. I came home, I consumed everything I could surrounding the character and discovered how deeply they’d leaned into that background: she comes from a world that’s had weapons tested on it while the people watched arms dealers swan around in furs. She’s a refugee who left after a village was space napalmed for daring to protest. Her homeworld was upended in a series of CIA style destabilization coups and efforts. Her homeworld was destroyed while the First Order spouted lines taken straight from the US interventionist textbook while the space UN shrugged and absolved itself of the responsibility. 

But just a few days before I watched it my pal @chamerionwrites​ pointed out to me that the TLJ marketing was partnered, in part, with Dole. Unite for a healthy galaxy is not a particularly insidious phrase but it does take on a blackly comedic veneer when you consider that Dole has spent quite a bit on PR trying to shut down any criticism by Nicaraguan workers who insist the illegal pesticides they’ve been using on their bananas have had serious health repercussions for them. Or that Dole is owned by the DOW chemical company who to this day, refuses to accept its responsibility in the Bhopal Gas tragedy. It takes on an even more macabre and almost Dr Strangelove-esque parody of itself when you consider Dole’s history: founded from the Hawaiian Pineapple Company and the Standard Fruit Company, the latter of which along with Chiquita/United Fruit singlehandedly gave us the term banana republic and in the Cold War, fuelled right wing death squads in Central America. Or take, for example, the history of DOW during Vietnam: a manufacturer of Agent Orange and Napalm for the US government. 

Unite For A Healthy Galaxy, as the Vietnamese actress tells us about space colonialism and the military industrial complex and the extended canon tells us she escaped as a refugee after the space napalming of a village on her planet. 

Here’s another example: in December 2016 I watched Rogue One and was quietly thrilled to see the film so clearly frame the Empire on Jedha in distinct visual terms that echoed the US occupation in Iraq. A couple of months later, Marvel (which does the Star Wars comics, which at that time was doing the Ashes of Jedha run, if I’m not mistaken), was forced to back down from a deal with Northrop Grumman only after sustained public pressure from multiple quarters. 

I, personally, can’t square my leftist ideals with this kind of self-parodic dark comedy. It’s great leftist comedy though, I’ll give you that: it shows you just how empty all of this actually is. 

But if you want to know about the narrative itself:

I don’t think Star Wars is one or the other tbh. It has leftist elements thrown in with reactionary elements. The new canon leans hard into some of the more leftist elements; the old canon was more definitively reactionary. Liberal, but of a more reactionary tenor. A good part of the reason why is because I don’t think you can get anything genuinely leftist out of mainstream Hollywood; at the most you might get some director or screenwriter’s vaguely leftist tendencies shining through but I think its also an industry that settles for creators who are safely inside the lines of provocative leftist thought. And Star Wars is a big blockbuster now, which means it has to be kept open enough to appeal to a wide enough segment of people who will prop up the franchise and make it worth Disney’s while to keep pouring money into it. Sure, you get some interesting moments in the extended canon but I don’t think its enough to weigh it one way or the other because at the heart of it Star Wars is still very much a thing that’s an artifact of George Lucas’ creation and all the things he put into it – these reactionary influences like wossface’s monomyth analyses, his lowkey racism & colonialist attitudes, his sexism, his obsession with westerns and heroic war films (and their place in the arsenal of US Cold War prop) – very much still linger on in the confines of the franchise.

Sometimes the new canon tries a little fixing. Sometimes its a little broken. Sometimes you get a story about droid rebellion and droid rights that kind of looks neat, except in the end everything about the droid rights is a cult. Sometimes you get what seems like the beginning of an anti-colonial story led by characters who are all played, as someone put it, as Storm/front style racist caricatures only for the narrative to turn around and scream at you for daring to find any kind of truth in them (they’re all power hungry, corrupt, violent or cruel; there are no true believers). Sometimes someone will try and correct these ridiculously racist stereotypes, but leave the structure in place: a genuine anti-colonial movement that situated the Republic as colonizer? Impossible and wrong. 

There’s just about enough room for me to stick my middle finger up at the canon, but frankly I think squaring it with my leftist ideals is a sisyphean and ultimately useless effort. I take the good and then, making eye contact with Lucasfilm, shoot the canon and do whatever the hell I want with everything else. 

¯\_(ツ)_/¯

title: Return of the Wrath
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2ve5td9

by Quinny_Imp

DEFUNCT STORY

It was written long ago, and was rendered moot by the events of the game that came after KOTET.

So it’s falls into “what would happen if” category.

What would happen if Attira decided to take the Imperial Throne.

Words: 2722, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Star Wars Legends: The Old Republic
  • Rating: Not Rated
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings

title: You're Nothing Like Him
description:
by MoonlightSalsa

“No! I know what you’re about to say so don’t say it! I don’t know where you got the idea of me not wanting to be with you anymore, but it’s not true! You’re kind and sweet and caring and you’re my best friend! Being the son of Vader won’t change that!”

blog.name: captainpikeachu
blog.title: this blog stans king bran of house stark FUCK YEAH
blog.description: belinda | 27 | earthling "it's been a long day without you, my friend, and i'll tell you all about it when i see you again"

summary:
after rewatching the last jedi and some eps from the clone wars, I love Luke’s story even more now
lmao 😂 
it is only right that...
body:
after rewatching the last jedi and some eps from the clone wars, I love Luke’s story even more now

lmao 😂

it is only right that Luke’s true success from his training was the capacity for maximum trolling

Yoda and Obi Wan failed Luke in every aspect except they certainly passed on the trolling

Luke Skywalker, trolling master, a legend

Luke Skywalker, a troll, like his masters before him
